Subject: RE: [junit] Using JUnit in GPL licensed projects

Hi Joachim, 

> how can junit be used in gpl projects? I think it's not 
> possible to publish junit based tests of gpl software. 
> Junit tests cannot be published under gpl because licenses 
> are incompatible. 
> Tests that use gpl code have to be published under the gpl. q.e.d.
> Has anybody experiences with this topic? Any thoughts?

I've been researching this in trying to select a license for NUnitLite. For
a serious opinion, consult an attorney, but here's what I think is true.

Licenses need interpretation. What counts first is the interpretation and
intent of the person who holds the copyright to the GPLed project. If they
don't think you're in violation, they won't sue you and nobody else has
standing. So one thing to do is to ask the copyright holders if they believe
publishing your tests requires licensing the tests. If they say there's no
problem, then there's no problem. If they say it is a problem, you have to
decide whether to take the risk based on what you think a court would do.

What about Junit? Does publishing your tests mean you have to license them
under CPL? Or license them at all? I don't think so (but IANAL). According
to that license, works that are separate modules and not "derivative works"
of Junit are not required to use CPL. Do the authors of Junit think that the
CPL license provision should apply to your tests? You can ask that question
right here.

I usually just lurk here, but I responded because I think this is a big
issue for the testing community. If we're in favor of free/open source
software, and also in favor of publishing tests, then we need to come to
some understanding that publishing the tests of your application does not
put you under any reciprocal obligations to the authors of the test
framework you are using.

It seems to me that writing tests is part of the "use" of a test framework
and doesn't amount to the same thing as extending it, say by publishing a
SuperJUnit framework that included the original. If I, as a framework
author, were to sue you for writing and publishing tests that use my
framework, I'd look pretty silly.

That said, people need assurances. I think NUnitLite will have a notice that
explains our intention to not inforce any licensing requirements against
published tests, so long as they are only tests of a particular application
and not a general-purpose program. Maybe it would be useful if we all did
something like that.

Charlie
